title: Taron-Crystals Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Taron-Crystals oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is used to make the urine less acidic. This effect helps the [kidneys](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) get rid of uric acid, thereby helping to prevent [gout](https://www.webmd.com/arthritis/arthritis-gout) and [kidney stones](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/ss/slideshow-kidney-stones-overview). This medication can also prevent and treat certain metabolic problems (acidosis) caused by [kidney disease](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-kidney-disease-basic-information).Citric acid and citrate salts (which contain [potassium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-potassium) and sodium) belong to a class of drugs known as urinary alkalinizers. If you have a condition that requires you to limit your intake of potassium and sodium, your doctor may direct you to take a product that is lower in potassium and sodium. How to use Taron-Crystals Packet Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) as directed by your doctor, usually 4 times a day after meals and at [bedtime](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/childs-bedtime). To help prevent [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), take each dose after a meal. To prevent [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach) upset/injury, mix your prescribed dose of medication in cold water or juice as directed. Drink the entire mixture slowly. If you still have [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/rm-quiz-surprising-stomach-facts) upset, mixing your dose in a larger amount of liquid may help unless your doctor directs you otherwise. Ask your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) for further instructions. The liquid form of this medication must be mixed with at least 4 - 8 ounces (120 - 240 milliliters) of water before taking. Shake the bottle well before each dose and carefully measure the dose using a special measuring device/spoon. Do not use a household spoon because you may not get the correct dose. If you are using the powdered/crystal form of this medication, mix the contents of the packet in at least 3/4 cup (6 ounces or 180 milliliters) of cool water or juice before taking. Refrigerating the mixture before drinking may improve the taste. Drink more water or juice after taking this medication unless otherwise directed by your doctor. Dosage is based on your medical condition and response to treatment. Take this medication exactly as prescribed. Do not increase your dose or take this more often without your doctor's approval. Use this medication regularly to get the most benefit from it. To help you remember, take it at the same times each day. While taking this medication, you may need to test the pH (acidity) of your urine using special paper. The pH will help determine the proper dose. Consult your doctor or pharmacist for more information. Side Effects [Nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), and [stomach pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments) may occur. Mixing the [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with water or juice, taking it after meals, and drinking more fluids will help prevent these side effects. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. Remember that this medication has been prescribed because your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: severe [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach)/ [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics), bloody/black/tarry stools, vomit that looks like coffee grounds. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions Before taking this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this medication, tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical problems (such as [peptic ulcers](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/peptic-ulcer-overview), irritable bowel). Liquid forms of this product may contain sugar. Caution is advised if you have [diabetes](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/diabetes-health-check/default.htm). Ask your doctor or pharmacist about using this product safely. During pregnancy, this medication should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. It is unknown if this drug passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this drug are: antacids that contain aluminum, [aspirin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-3-ASPIRIN+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=1082&drugname=Aspirin+Oral) and other [salicylates](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/salicylate-allergy) salsalate), certain [spironolactone](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-6288/spironolactone+oral/details), [triamterene](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-10326/triamterene+oral/details)). directed you for [heart attack](https://www.webmd.com/heart-disease/heart-disease-heart-attacks) or [stroke prevention](https://www.webmd.com/stroke/tc/stroke-cause) (usually 81-162 milligrams a day), you should continue taking it unless your doctor instructs you otherwise. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) may include: slow heartbeat, [muscle spasms](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/muscle-spasms-cramps-charley-horse), [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics). Do not share this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with others. Lab and/or medical tests (such as [potassium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-potassium) levels) should be done while you are taking this medication. Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from heat, light, and moisture. Do not freeze. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
